content: @WG-async-sprint-planning meeting in ~70 minutes at 2021-09-30T09:00:00-07:00. please update the sprint planning doc if you have time.
hey @WG-async-sprint-planning
time for our meeting

Agenda for today:

  • Sprint retrospective
  • Assign [polish issues]
  • Identify sprint goals
Perhaps we can take a few minutes at the beginning to update the planning doc?
howdy

https://twitter.com/nikomatsakis/status/1443608343411630097

New @rustlang blog post: https://smallcultfollowing.com/babysteps//blog/2021/09/30/dyn-async-traits-part-1/ First in a series digging into dyn async traits, starting by setting up the general problem.

- Niko Matsakis (@nikomatsakis)
ok
Sprint retrospective
How'd it go?
I'd say for async fundamentals, it felt pretty good. I liked having the concrete, achievable goals.
It looks like we didn't make much progress on the polish issues :)
I think for fundamentals we got everything done, though I was finishing things up last night and this morning :)
That counts!
@tmandry has a PR out for his polish issue!
I do have a PR for mine too, though I don't think I want to land it, but @oli is exploring an alternative approach
I never got to my second polish issue, but I did get a pr accepted that adds the must_not_suspend attr to things like mutexguard in std, so we can dogfood
yes, though I think mine was simple compared to some of the other ones
I should add that a few people have asked me about issues
I feel like I made good progress on the generator liveness stuff and the other issue I volunteered for, but I sort of spaced on the administrative tasks I planned to do. Sorry about that!
ok
@nikomatsakis - like they are asking for suggestions for good issues to work on?
Right, I should send them to you :)
Yes please :)
I would say spending all your time on administrative stuff is an anti-pattern, but spending none of it is too :). It does provide useful context and documentation for people outside the effort
yes
agreed
@Esteban Küber did you say you filed a lang team issue?
er, a lang team proposal?
if so I don't see it :)
@nikomatsakis I have it written, I'm planing on filing the ticket tomorrow (I can leave it "open" until I do so if that's better)
ah, ok!
(was working on that today)
that's fine :)
I guess same with blog post?
Correct (I'm setting up a place to publish using GH pages, don't have a blog :sweat_smile:)
(shall we discuss next sprint goals?)

tmandry said:

I would say spending all your time on administrative stuff is an anti-pattern, but spending none of it is too :). It does provide useful context and documentation for people outside the effort

I would like initiative pages etc. to provide an on-ramp but that stuff is easy to forgot, that's why I made the issue template checklists

nikomatsakis said:

(shall we discuss next sprint goals?)

polish issues are first :)
but yeah, let's move on
@triagebot end-topic

Does anyone have something to add on the current topic?
React with :working_on_it: if you have something to say.
React with :all_good: if not.

Polish issues

Project board
so
I'm planning to keep working on #74256
yeah, I was going to say that I think it's better for us to go "deep" than "broad" and try taking on too many things
Yeah, a few finished tasks are better than many unfinished tasks.
e.g. while I was working on my issue that led me to a related issue I think I'd like to tackle next
It might make sense to triage the tickets to see if there's any that could be E-easy for people looking for things to do

eholk said:

Yeah, a few finished tasks are better than many unfinished tasks.

yes. also, building up context is the most expensive part, in my experience
As is context switching
I will look into https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues/71723
I hate that error
Does anyone have a suggestion on what might be a good place for me to look next?
Are there more issues your team is hitting at work, @Gus Wynn ?
Picking one off the top of "on deck" is not a terrible strategy :)
Perhaps #87613?

nikomatsakis said:

I will look into https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues/71723

The output for that one has changed since it was filed (still not great)

I can't think of any polish issues that are not yet claimed that I remember. For me, I think the real main problems are how to correctly interleave blocking and non-blocking work, and also spawning with borrowing (so basically the scope api that has been mentioned), but thats not really polish

tmandry said:

Picking one off the top of "on deck" is not a terrible strategy :smile:

will take a look
I'm going to work on improving compiler errors when returning Pin::new(async {}) from a function with a Pin<Box<>> return type

maybe https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues/78149, as I just looked at that code. At least I can do this part: "In the short term we could make a lint to warn people who use the attribute on async fns that it won't do anything."
sounds good :)
we should talk about goals for next sprint!
ok
Identify sprint goals
one thing that @nikomatsakis brought up is that we still need to identify stakeholders for many initiatives
(this is another item I put in the checklist so we don't lose it :) )
Yes, that's a good goal. I want us to have 3-5 stakeholders for async fundamentals; I imagine generators could use the same
@tmandry and I had prepared this stakeholder plan for async fundamentals
I was thinking about posting a blog post on Inside Rust about it
we could do a more general one, including other groups, potentially?
yeah. though if we are looking for a small number it might be better to reach out to individuals first?
In any case, we can take some time to write goals down in the doc

tmandry said:

yeah. though if we are looking for a small number it might be better to reach out to individuals first?

maybe, let's discuss after
(I don't really expect to find people via a blog post, the goal there is more to advertise that we are doing it, though I thought we might find someone unexpected, you never know)
(plus it's easy to point people at a blog post when you talk to them)
makes sense
for us Tyler -- I am thinking -- we outlined the MVP
I think a reasonable goal might to draft an RFC :)
but maybe that's getting ahead of ourselves
still, I think we could write one without that much difficulty
hm, for the MVP it probably won't be too controversial, yeah
(ugh sorry all I had a conflicting meeting and missed beginning of this)
@pnkfelix no worries. we're identifying sprint goals now
I am thinking what would be another good goal...
I think beyond the RFC, I would like to have something about exploring one of the next steps, but I'm not sure what. I guess dyn

@nikomatsakis you had stuck these somewhere in the doc, not sure if you want to carry them forward

  • [ ] Extend and land #230, generally "tighten up" the async foundations landing page -- nikomatsakis
  • [ ] Extend roadmap vision to include async fn main and to mention the "task-local auto trait" problem -- nikomatsakis
Yeah, I do, but I really need to actually do them
I might have time for that later today or tomorrow, I have some time to kill where I have low connectivity
@Esteban Küber so...posting blogpost...is there a kind of "MVP" you can identify too?
that might make a nice goal
Yes, sorry, didn't update :)
I want to publish the WIP branch I had for parser changes
(ideally something that could be stabilized without significant progress elsewhere, which could be hard for async generators -- maybe possible for sync?)
obviously we'd have to build consensus around syntax etc, I'm thinking more about "core capabilities"
(I don't expect this to be the final syntax, because everyone hates it for one reason or another)
@tmandry of the various challenges we enumerated, which would you expect us to continue focusing our discussion on? I think dyn
fair enough... the other thing I wanted to look at was expanding the ItemKind enum to add the new IteratorItem (but haven't scoped that up yet)
maybe the right goal is "prototype x", @Esteban Küber ?

nikomatsakis said:

I think beyond the RFC, I would like to have something about exploring one of the next steps, but I'm not sure what. I guess dyn

Yeah continuing to explore dyn is good.. but maybe we should pick off some of the smaller challenges?

  • Naming async fn return types
  • Bounding async fn return types as Send?
"smaller" :)
those are scarier to me lol
I almost put that in quotes :)
Well, naming the return types doesn't seem that scary to me :)
still, I think that the "fallback" of having some way to name the type of a function
seems useful and gives a way to name a return type
even if I think it may be very unergonomic in some circumstances
but I think it has general utility
there's also manual desugaring
so maybe it's not very urgent
anyway, we could certainly have a goal of like "enumerating the alternatives and having a recommendation" for "naming aync fn return types" (kind of: write that part of the eval doc)
another thought, but it might be a goal for next sprint, not this one: hold first stakeholder meeting and get feeedback on options (e.g., trait multiplication :)
I think that's more for next sprint

nikomatsakis said:

anyway, we could certainly have a goal of like "enumerating the alternatives and having a recommendation" for "naming aync fn return types" (kind of: write that part of the eval doc)

that's a very achievable task imo
let's do that
wait, naming async fn return types is for async fn in traits right?
I have a whole series of blog posts just laying out the stuff we've already said on dyn so ... that'll take a while :)
@Gus Wynn yeah

Gus Wynn said:

wait, naming async fn return types is for async fn in traits right?

yeah, proabably any -> impl Trait in traits

nikomatsakis said:

I have a whole series of blog posts just laying out the stuff we've already said on dyn so ... that'll take a while :)

want to add a blog post to the sprint?
we could, but I was just posting on my personal blog, didn't think of it as a "sprint activity"
more like "it'd be helpful to me to try and write this stuff out in detail"
ok
not sure, @pnkfelix, do you plan any kind of sprint goals? I know you're pretty busy with other prep work right now
I still have goals from previous sprint
I think they all remain relevant
and I just need to … do them.
not sure if it will happen in next two weeks
in any case, I don’t have new goals to add.
would it be more realistic to focus on just 1 or 2?
to be clear: when I said “not sure if …”, i sort of meant I wasn’t sure if any of them would
but I think I can make time for the high level thing
the administrativa for tooling
ok
I'd like it if carry-over goals are copied to the heading for this meeting
so there's one "source of truth" active in the doc at a given time
I think we can move to the point where we share the sprint goals for each area and discuss
okay

General

  • [ ] Extend and land #230, generally "tighten up" the async foundations landing page -- nikomatsakis
  • [ ] Extend roadmap vision to include async fn main and to mention the "task-local auto trait" problem -- nikomatsakis

(already discussed some)

Async fundamentals

  • [ ] Reach out to stakeholders and identify 1-5
  • [ ] Draft RFC for MVP
  • [ ] Write up the alternatives for naming async-fn-in-trait return types and come up with a recommendation

Async iteration

  • [ ] Prototype basic sync iterator item (independent of current generator machinery, but reusing it)
  • [ ] Gather feedback from blogpost

Polish

  • [ ] [ongoing] (estebank) Unhelpful compiler message when a reference is used inside of an await block #723120
  • [ ] (tmandry) Improve compiler error when returning Pin::new(async {}) (continuation of #89390, issue TBD)
  • [ ] (eholk) Continue working on "E0623 highlights wrong parameter in async fn" #74256

Other polish goals:

  • [ ] (eholk) Set up initiative for testing that sync and async programs have the same behavior
  • [ ] (eholk) Follow up with lang-team about liveness-based generator captures
  • [ ] (eholk) Continue generator liveness implementation
  • [ ] (eholk) Fill out landing pages for polish initiatives
  • [ ] (eholk) Assign async polish label to issues

Tooling

  • [ ] Add entry for (tokio-)console to Tooling roadmap in async vision doc - pnkfelix
  • [ ] Post console-subscriber into crates.io (preview version, at least) - pnkfelix
My polish goals are basically all carry over from last sprint, with the high order bit being to stay on top of administrative tasks this time
oh I think mw had something ongoing for crashdumps, let me double check
oh yeah, its done: Add team for async-crashdump-debugging initiative.
from context I saw, I think this was so an initiative repo could be created
yeah
so I guess that’s the next step
oh, here it is: https://github.com/rust-lang/async-crashdump-debugging-initiative
or no, that is the initiative
right
okay
sorry for distraction
no worries, glad you brought it up
okay, any other comments, questions, observations?

I would say I want to focus on making sprint goals achievable and well-scoped. A stretch goal or two is not a bad idea, but it's really nice to be able to mark things as completed and I worry it's going to be discouraging to continually be carrying things over.
